table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {B Sa A:sen:nolink} "A rhymes with B" ▶ {Sachuq A B:sen:nolink} "A and B rhyme"

table.name: mem
table.column: The subject is what's undergoing expansion.
This is used erroneously in a line in the {paq'batlh:src}: {qo'maj wISachmeH maSuv:sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be amplified, fleshed out, elaborated, increased in scope, etc.

This is an expansion of the meaning of the existing verb {Sach:v:1}.[1]
In the context of zooming (see {jo':v:2}), this can be used for "be magnified".[2]

▶ {paq SachmoH.:sen@@paq:n:1h, Sach:v:2, -moH:v} (if someone makes an expanded version of a book)[1] ▶ {Sach paq.:sen@@Sach:v:2, paq:n:1h} "the book expands"[1] ▶ {paq Sach:n@@paq:n:1h, Sach:v:2} "an extended book"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
Another variant of this word which is used with roughly equal frequency is {SanID:n:num,nolink}.
This is a number-forming element, and not itself a number. The number 1000 (one thousand) is {wa'SaD:n:num,nolink} in Klingon.
Note that Klingon has number-forming elements for "ten thousand" ({netlh:n:num}) and "hundred thousand" ({bIp:n:num}) which are independent of the word for "thousand".
While {SaD law':n:nolink} is a grammatical expression, {SaDmey:n:nolink} is not.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: To indicate "millennia ago" or "millennia from now", {ret:n} and {pIq:n} are used in place of {poH:n}, respectively.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a short-scale billion (i.e., one thousand million).[1]
For tens of billions, the number-forming elements {maHSaghan:n:num@@maH:n:2, Saghan:n} or {netlh'uy':n:num@@netlh:n, 'uy':n} are possible.[2]
For hundreds of billions, the number-forming elements {vatlhSaghan:n:num@@vatlh:n, Saghan:n} or {bIp'uy':n:num@@bIp:n, 'uy':n} are possible.[2]
For trillions, the number-forming elements {SaDSaghan:n:num@@SaD:n, Saghan:n} or {SanIDSaghan:n:num@@SanID:n, Saghan:n} are possible.[2]
The astronomer Carl Sagan was famous for saying "billions and billions".

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not defined as such, but to translate "apathy" or "apathy creature" for the Klingon Christmas Carol, one of MO's suggestions was {SaHHa'wI':n:nolink} "one who is not concerned".[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
Animals kept by pets as Klingons include the {targh:n}, the {Qogh:n}, and the {'er:n}. Terrans also keep an animal resembling the {vIghro':n} as pets.
Commands given to pets should be preceded by the word {SuH:excl}, and always be in clipped Klingon.[2]
The English translation of the sentence from {Star Trek Constellations:src} does not appear in the book, but in the author's annotations which was a separate document.
▶ {chobelHa'moH, DI'qar. SajlIj 'oHbe' quvwIj'e'.:sen:nolink} "You disappoint me, D'Kar. My honor is not your plaything."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column:
Based on its usage in the {paq'batlh:src}, the thing being ascended is the object, and the destination is marked with {-Daq:n}.[2]
This word is not used for sort order.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: See the example for an illustration of the difference between this word and {nej:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The verb {chenmoH:v} can be used with {San:n}.[2]
This was defined as "fate" in {TKD:src}. It was explained in a {KLI mailing list:src} message that "destiny" is another possible translation.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a scar which is the result of a wound received in the course of a fight or battle.
This was defined as just "scar", with an accompanying explanation of the kinds of scars.

table.name: mem
table.column: From lowest to highest, these ranks are: {tay:n:3}, {Sutay:n}, {veStay:n}, {Santay:n:nolink}, {'Iptay:n}.
This is a rank from John M. Ford's 1984 novel "The Final Reflection". These ranks are used by many Klingon fan clubs, despite not appearing in canon (i.e., in any TV episode or movie).

table.name: mem
table.column: Silicon Valley is located in Santa Clara.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to an individual plant, typically with stems, leaves, etc. It is not used for fungi or algae.
"Red Menace". During the middle of the 20th century, the House Committee on Un-American Activities investigated Hollywood and accused various people of being Communist "plants".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a unit of information in computer science.
Claude Shannon was the founder of information theory.

table.name: mem
table.column: land (alight on the ground, like a bird)
If a bird lands on a tree, the verb {ngun:v} is used, and if on water, then {tlhot:v}.[2] The landing site (see {SaqDaq:n}) is marked with {-Daq:n:suff}.[4]

Land "shark" from SNL.
This was defined as "land" in {TKD:src}. The clarification was added based on {HQ 10.4:src}, which says "the verb {Saq:v:nolink} is used if the bird alights on the ground".

▶ {SaqtaHvIS toQDuj wa'vatlh loS vI' jav chorgh 'uj 'ab 'oH:sen:nolink} "Landing Formation Height: 36.46 M"[3] ▶ {tera' jar Soch, DIS wa' Hut jav Hut, maSDaq SaqmeH Qu' wa'DIch HochHom turlu'taHvIS, wej logh lengwI'pu' pa'mey 'oH Apollo wa'maH wa' ra'ghom bobcho' Columbia'e'.:sen:nolink} "The Apollo 11 Command Module, 'Columbia,' was the living quarters for the three-person crew during most of the first manned lunar landing mission in July 1969."[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the native region of {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name} on {Qo'noS:n:place}, and the location of his estate.

This was apparently intended to mean "hero's land". The inventor of the word either made a mistake in looking up "land" (which, as a noun, should be {puH:n} rather than {Saq:v}), or simply preferred the look or sound of "Saq'sub".

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons have no tear ducts, and there is no word for tear or tears. However, Klingons eyes do redden ({DoqchoH:v:nolink}) from time to time.[2] They would also understand {mIn 'onroS:n} to refer to a teardrop.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This means "variety" in the sense of "an interesting variety of tea", not "variety is the spice of life".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be shallow, be superficial, be uncritical; be unfortunate, be not good
This word is applied to a person to disparage his or her intellect. It is also used by itself as an expression of disapproval, similar to {Do'Ha'.:sen}[1, p.164]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used for situations like being stuck in a meeting or stuck in traffic. It's also used for a cat stuck in a tree.
This was defined as "be stuck" with an explanation, along with a bunch of other words which can be translated into various senses of "be stuck" in English.

table.name: mem
table.column: The first and second {yu:n} in the Klingon musical scale are a nonave apart.

table.name: mem
table.column: {Sawchuq:v@@Saw:v, -chuq:v} would be understood as a same-sex marriage between two men.[2]
MO confirmed at {qep'a' 4 (1997):src} that {Saw:v:nolink} and {nay:v:nolink} come from "sure" and "no" said with a Southern drawl.

table.name: mem
table.column:
To use a gesture is {Sawlay lo':sen@@Sawlay:n, lo':v} or else a specific gesture verb (such as {SIq:v}, {qay:v}, etc.).
Maltz didn't know a generic verb for this.[1]
In Chinese, "伴手禮" means souvenir (a gift given when traveling). In particular, "手" means "hand".

table.name: mem
table.column: This word was revealed during a session of singing and dancing the Hokey Pokey. It is the Yiddish word "tuchus" written backwards.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is an extension of {Sa'Hut:n:1} to the back of something, in which case the front would be {logh'ob:n:2} and the sides would be {reD:n:3}.[1] In this usage, the plural is formed with {-mey:n:suff}.[2]
This can apply to cars, motorcycles, space ships and the like, but not to the back of a computer screen (too flat) or a bottle (because it's round). There's an overlap with {'o':n}, but whereas {'o':n:nolink} refers to a 3-dimensional space, {Sa'Hut:n:2,nolink} refers to the surface at the back.[3]

An explanation of {logh'ob:n:2,nolink}, {Sa'Hut:n:2,nolink}, and {reD:n:3,nolink} was given during the Q & A session at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2021:src}.
This was defined as "back". The clarification "exterior surface" was added based on the explanation.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a large region several thousand kilometers east of the First City ({veng wa'DIch:n}). In the dialect of this region, prepositionals take suffixes (see under {lurgh:n} for an explanation). Furthermore, toasts follow the normal word order, with the subject following the verb (see {-jaj:v}).
This region contains {HuD beQ yoS:n}.

This is basically "jackass" spelled backwards.
This word appears only in the body of {KGT:src} and not in the glossary.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a ceremonial position whose role is to activate the Beacon of Kahless.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is for driving things which are self-powered, so it would not be used for a bicycle, for example.[2]
That this verb is used for self-powered vehicles only was clarified during the Q & A session at {qep'a' 28 (2021):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Segh - bI'rel tlharghDuj:sen:nolink} "Model - B'rel Scout"[2] ▶ {Hem tlhIngan Segh 'ej maHemtaH 'e' wIHech.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: Usage of this outside of set, accepted expressions such as {bIQ SeHjan:n} is considered odd.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be used for a "settings" or "preferences" page in software, but not individual settings, which are {DuH:n}.[2]
Some information was revealed about {SeH:n:archaic,hyp,nolink} at {qep'a' 27 (2020):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {leng Dotlh SeHwI' pat:n} ▶ {muD ngeb SeHwI' pat:n}

table.name: mem
table.column: Small children, or adults talking to or about small children, use {rIl:v:1} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: Small children, or adults talking to or about small children, use {rIlwI':n} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: The non-slang way to say this is {nguy:v}.
It was hypothesised during the Q & A session that this might have originated as a gesture (see {Sen:v:1}), but MO wasn't sure.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is also a slang term, {ruqwI':n}.
St. George's is the capital of Grenada.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the name of a Federation starship (神舟 in Chinese).
As this is a non-Klingon name, there is some variation in how Klingons pronounce it. Some pronounce it more like {Senjaw:n:name,nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons breed some small animals for food.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an extension of {Sep:v:1} to mathematics.

This word was not given an English definition, but in the definition of {qovDa':n:nolink} it was explained that "the idea of raising a number to the power of something is generally expressed by" using this verb.

table.name: mem
mem
mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {let mInDu'Daj; Separmey rur@@let:v, mIn:n, -Du':n, -Daj:n, Separ:n, -mey:n, rur:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be formal, be ritualistic, be ceremonial

table.name: mem
table.column: It if emits only water, then it's just a {ghItwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Backwards of "roses". "The Subject Was Roses" was a play adapted into a 1968 film.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the chemical element with the symbol As and atomic number 33.
"Arsenic and Old Lace" ({'oltlheS:sen:nolink}) is the name of a 1944 film.

table.name: mem
table.column: The existence of the homophonous verb {Sev:v} may suggest that Klingons view the containment of wounds as being analogous to the containment of an enemy.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is listed among other militaristic terminology in the body of {KGT:src} on p.48.
The existence of the homophonous noun {Sev:n} may suggest that Klingons view the containment of wounds as being analogous to the containment of an enemy.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be applied to music.[2, p.71]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is composed of {Se':n} and {tu':v}, which suggests that Klingons believe Terran saucepans to be satellite dishes. According to the explanation by {qe'San:n:name,nolink}, this was apparently based on "set-to" because there was a heated discussion about it.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to a publication of any kind, whether printed or not.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a pun on the name of a well-known Terran publishing house. (The pun was confirmed by Okrand to {'ISqu':n:name}.[3])

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a device used for two-way communication. For the device which receives (but does not send) an audio signal, see {wab HevwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: An English definition has never been given for this word. Its meaning is inferred from the only example of its usage.
▶ {chaw'vam yIpol 'ej SIbI'Ha' yIlo' pagh 'oH yImech.} "This card may be kept until needed or traded."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The example sentence from {DSC - Such Sweet Sorrow, Part 2:src} was composed by someone other than Okrand, most probably Robyn Stewart ({Qov:n:name}).
[1] {TKD:src}, [2] {paq'batlh 2ed p.150-151:src}, [3] {KLI mailing list 2019.04.09:src}, [4] {DSC - Such Sweet Sorrow, Part 2:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: The actor Sid James played a patient in "Carry On Doctor". There are a number of medical abbreviations written "SID".

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can be used for the raising of eyebrows (see {Huy':n}).[2]

This was defined as just "bend" in {TKD:src}. The revelation of {SIHHa'moH:v} confirmed that it is intransitive. The definition was clarified to "bend, be bent" at the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2020:src}. (Despite the "be" in the definition, it seems that this isn't a verb describing a state or quality. Rather, the clarification is intended to be read in the same way as "move, be in motion" was for {vIH:v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: The non-slang way to say this is {pan:v:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qaStaHvIS wa' ram loS SaD Hugh SIjlaH qetbogh loD.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: When used in the slang sense, this verb does not take an object.[1, p.164]

table.name: mem
table.column: type of knife (used for food preparation)
This is used for finer work in cooking.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to "Through the Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There", the sequel to "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland".

table.name: mem
table.column: [1] {DSC - Si Vis Pacem, Para Bellum:src}, [2] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: See under {boq:v:2} for the basic mathematical operations.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the amount of energy transferred or converted per unit time.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a unit of temperature on a specific scale, not the generic word for a unit of temperature.
Some reference temperatures for the {SImyon:sen:nolink} scale (left) vs. Celsius (right) are: 0 = -210 freezing point of Nitrogen 96 = -100 100 = -95 183 = 0 freezing point of water 200 = 19 215 = 37 body temperature (Human/Klingon) 270 = 100 boiling point of water - Earth sea level 273 = 103 boiling point of water - {Qo'noS:n} observatory 300 = 134 500 = 363 1000 = 937 temperature of molten lava

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the geographic tool, not the drawing tool.
This is what early compasses were called in China (司南).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a non-scientific, general term for an ancient (extinct) animal of any size (though often quite large).
The logo and mascot of the Sinclair Oil Corporation is a large green dinosaur. The protagonist of the Disney series Dinosaurs was named Earl Sinclair.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {yIn nI' yISIQ 'ej yIchep!:sen} ▶ {pIj tay'taH Doch pIm:sen}
This is the first officer of the {'entepray':n:name} under {jemS tIy qIrq:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
When used with nouns marked with {-Daq:n}, the finger verbs mean "point (with that finger) at or towards" the object indicated by that noun.
There are some special cases of the reflexive (with {-'egh:v}) forms of the finger verbs. See the example below, and also under {rIl:v:1}.
If an implement is used for an activity typically performed by a finger, a finger verb may be used.

▶ {maghwI'Daq jISIq.:sen:nolink} "I point at the traitor with my index finger."[1] ▶ {ghIchwIj vISIq.:sen:nolink} "I touch my nose with my index finger."[1] ▶ {ghIchwIjDaq jISIq:sen:nolink} "I point at my nose with my index finger."[1] ▶ {ghIchwIjDaq jISIq'egh.:sen:nolink} "I pick my nose with my index finger."[1] ▶ {maghwI'Daq SIq naQjejwIj.:sen:nolink} "My spear points at the traitor."[1] ▶ {ghIq chalDaq HovDaq SIq qeylIS 'ej jatlh pa' DaqHomvetlh wovDaq HInej.:sen}[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of small person in Klingon mythology, like an elf or a gnome.[1] It might be used to translate creatures such as "dwarf" or "fairy" in Terran mythology as well, though it might not be appropriate for translating the term "fairy tale".[2]
The information that it can also be used to translate "dwarf" or "fairy" was not directed posted to the mailing list, but was also revealed in the discussion about translating The Wizard of Oz.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons use {SIQ:v:nolink} rather than {tIv:v} for some things that humans might consider pleasant or neutral.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just the Klingon spelling for the name of the Terran board game.

table.name: mem
table.column: For "string" as in the variable type, see under {ghItlh:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "string doll", and refers to a doll which is used in puppet theatre performances.
This was defined as "puppet". The word "marionette" was added to distinguish this from {qo'rob:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Cyril Ritchard played Captain Hook in the 1954 Mary Martin production of the Broadway musical Peter Pan.

table.name: mem
table.column: Shirley Silver is an American linguist with whom Marc Okrand has worked in the past.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an old word. Maltz liked this better than {may' Sut:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: It's unknown how this compares to the becquerel.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Shiro is the mass of thread-like hyphae which constitutes the mycelium, or vegetative part, of a fungus. This word was revealed to translate "mycelial network" for {DSC:src}.
[1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - The Butcher's Knife Cares Not for the Lamb's Cry:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can take an object. Its subject is usually unstated.[2]

It's the sound of rain falling.
The sentence {chaHDaq SIStaHvIS negh 'Iw:sen:nolink} "[While they were] showered with the soldiers' blood" appeared in {paq'batlh 1ed p.136-137:src}, but this sentence was replaced in the 2ed with one which uses {ghay:v:nolink} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: MO said at the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src} that the apparent noun {SIS:n:hyp} is a fossilized remnant which is probably limited to this expression.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object. When used as the second verb in a sentence as object construction, it is usually translated as "wonder if".[2]
This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}, probably as a joke to make us wonder if it was a mistake.
▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh 'e' vISIv.:sen:nolink} "I wonder if you speak Klingon." This means something like, "I am curious about whether you speak Klingon."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: "C & H" is a brand of cane sugar.

table.name: mem
table.column: seventh tone of nonatonic musical scale
The tones of the Klingon musical scale (see {yutlhegh:n}) are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2,nolink}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This verb is used in the lyrics of the song {'ej HumtaH 'ej DechtaH 'Iw:sen}, where its subject is apparently {SIqral bIQtIq:n}. But since the lyrics are in {no' Hol:n}, it's not clear whether this gives any information as to how this verb should be used in modern standard Klingon.
"Sodden" means "completely soaked".

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: May the spirit of Kahless live within you.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word applies to both food and beverages[2], or anything consumed for sustenance.[4] A single dish or course is called a {nay':n}.[2]
This word carries the idiomatic meaning of "matter, concern, affair", for which see {Soj:n:2}.

This was defined as "food" in {TKD:src}, but {KGT:src} explains that it also applies to beverages.
The {SkyBox 21:src} example appears to be missing a conjunction.

▶ {yIntaHbogh tlhIngan Soj tlhol jablu'DI' tIvqu'lu'. qagh, ro'qegh'Iwachab, targh tIq Sop 'e' lungIl Humanpu' puS.:sen:nolink} "Klingon food is best when served fresh and live. Few humans dare to eat gagh, rokeg blood pie, or heart of targ."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an idiomatic meaning of the word {Soj:n:1}.
▶ {tlhIngan Soj 'oH; not bIyaj:sen:nolink} "It is a Klingon matter -- you'll never understand."

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the most frequently-heard way to refer to a replicator that produces food.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is rare unless the meal was interrupted.[1, p.102]

table.name: mem
table.column: Of course, {Soj naQmey:n:nolink} are always used in pairs.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a food storage room.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is usually served only on the most formal occasions.

table.name: mem
table.column: The verb to use for compiling such a list is {gher:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to food that no one has done anything to.[1, p.84]
The example appears to be missing a conjunction.

▶ {yIntaHbogh tlhIngan Soj tlhol jablu'DI' tIvqu'lu'. qagh, ro'qegh'Iwachab, targh tIq Sop 'e' lungIl Humanpu' puS.:sen:nolink} "Klingon food is best when served fresh and live. Few humans dare to eat gagh, rokeg blood pie, or heart of targ."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to any fishlike creature that has to come up to breathe air.[1]
"Thar she blows!" is a common saying on whaling ships when sighting a whale surfacing to breathe. It was popularised by the book "Moby Dick".

table.name: mem
table.column: "Soldes" is French for "sales". On English-French bilingual store signs one often sees "Sale / Soldes".

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unclear whether this verb is used for the relief of pain, anxiety, distress, etc., or for the removal of someone from active duty. If it is used for the latter, then it is related in meaning to {cho':v} and {gheS:v}, and perhaps it also forms the first part of {SonchIy:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a ceremony which either precedes or is the initial part of the Rite of Succession (see {cho'tay:n:hyp}).
Perhaps this word is related to {Son:v} and {che':v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Do not confuse this word with {QIch:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
There is an idiom, {lugh; Sor rur@@lugh:v, Sor:n, rur:v}[2], which may be connected to the verb {Sor:v}.
This word can also refer to the "club" suit in a deck of playing cards (see {Degh:n:1}).[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is connected with the idiom, {lugh; Sor rur@@lugh:v, Sor:n, rur:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: One kind of {Sor Hap 'In:n} is a tube which is open on both ends, with a longitudinal slit which doesn't go all the way to either end, and which is struck with a {mupwI'Hom:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the metallic chemical element with the symbol Cu and atomic number 29.
This is "kupros" backwards, a reference to "Cyprus" which is the origin of the English word "copper".

table.name: mem
table.column: The siblings of a {SoS:n:nolink} are {me':n} and {'IrneH:n}.

The joke with {vav:n:nolink} and {SoS:n:nolink} is that in most human languages, the words for "father" and "mother" contain simple labial sounds (typically either "b" or "p" for father, and "m" for mother), whereas the fricatives {v:sen:nolink} and {S:sen:nolink} are difficult sounds for human infants to make. Also, "SOS" is an internationally recognised distress signal.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was only spoken on {KCD:src}. The written form later appeared in the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src} booklet.

table.name: mem
table.column: A slang term is {QIm julHom:n} or even just {julHom:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can take {'e':n:pro} as its object.[2]
▶ {tlhIngan Hol Dajatlh 'e' vISov.:sen:nolink} "I know that you speak Klingon."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: In the {ruq'e'vet:n} dialect, this word is used instead of {ghIH:v:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The subject of this verb hides the object (or hides something in general, if there's no object).[3]
This verb is also used for the encryption of data (see {So':v:2}).

"Show".
The example {nuqDaq So'taH yaS?:sen:nolink} on {TKD p.69:src} is in error. As written, it would mean "Where is the officer hiding [something]?"[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just an application of {So':v:1} to data.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is also used for the decryption of data (see {So'Ha':v:2}).
This is not defined in canon, but is an obvious construction and is spoken in {Star Trek III:src} and {Star Trek V:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just an application of {So'Ha':v:1} to data. When this term is used for the decryption of data, it implies that the decryption is authorized and the way to do it is known.[1]
Despite the English definition, it may be the case that the grammar follows {So':v:1,nolink}, and that the subject is decrypted if there is no object.

table.name: mem
table.column: On {SkyBox 33:src}, the last two Klingon sentences were not translated into English: "A cloaking device that doesn't interfere with weapons has been installed on one ship in order to experiment. This ship was demonstrated on Stardate 9521.6 but it was destroyed." See the explanation under {ngongmeH Duj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a kind of surrogate parent role which is bestowed on a family friend who would care for a child if their parents were incapacitated. The closest analogy for the relation between a soh-chim and a child's parent is a stepbrother or stepsister.[2]
This term is gender-neutral and "godparent" is a good approximation. If a gender distinction needs to be made, {loD:n} or {be':n} can be added after {So'chIm:n:nolink}.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: be brave, be heroic, be bold, be valiant, be intrepid
This appears several times in the E-K word list under variations of the listed definitions (different orders and subsets of the terms).

table.name: mem
table.column: A "sub" (submarine sandwich) is also called a "hero" in some places. Also, "sub" is the opposite of "super" as in "superhero".

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also be used to mean "frequency" in constructions such as {wanI' SubmaH:n} or {yay SubmaH:n}. See {pe''egh:v} for an explanation of how to say something like "4 out of 5 points".
The slash used to separate the parts of a fraction is called the "solidus" ({Sub:v:1}, {maH:n:1}).

table.name: mem
table.column: The German verb for "to visit" is "besuchen".
▶ {vogh vISuch vIneH.:sen:nolink} "I want to visit some place."[2] ▶ {loHwI' vISuch 'e' vIpoQ!:sen}[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a dream that occurs when one is sleeping, and not in the sense of a hope, goal, or desire. It is also used to refer to a hallucination.[1]
This was rumoured to have been revealed at {qep'a' 26 (2019):src}, and was confirmed at {qep'a' 27 (2020):src} during the Q & A session.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word {SuDqu':v@@SuD:v:1, -qu':v} would probably be described as "green". {SuD 'ej wov:sen@@SuD:v:1, 'ej:conj, wov:v} refers to a yellowish tinge. ({SuD 'ach wov:sen@@SuD:v:1, 'ach:conj, wov:v} is also heard.)[2]

All natural languages found on Earth divide colours into "warm" and "cool" in the same way. Klingon distinguishes between {Doq:v} and {SuD:v:1,nolink}, but it groups "yellow" with the "cool" colours rather than with the "warm" colours.

▶ {SuD Dargh 'ej wov:sen@@SuD:v:1, Dargh:n, 'ej:conj, wov:v} "The tea is {SuD:v:1,nolink} and light"[2] ▶ {SuDbogh Dargh 'ej wovbogh:n@@SuD:v:1, -bogh:v, Dargh:n, 'ej:conj, wov:v, -bogh:v} (yellow tea)[2] ▶ {SuD 'ej wov:sen@@SuD:v:1, 'ej:conj, wov:v} or {SuD 'ach wov:sen@@SuD:v:1, 'ach:conj, wov:v} "light blue"[3] ▶ {SuD 'ej Hurgh:sen@@SuD:v:1, 'ej:conj, Hurgh:v} or {SuD 'ach Hurgh:sen@@SuD:v:1, 'ach:conj, Hurgh:v} "dark blue"[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: gamble, take a chance, take a risk
The example was placed here deliberately rather than in the {SuD:v:1} "be green" entry.

table.name: mem
table.column: The literal meaning of this idiomatic expression is "Fek'lhr's eyes are green".

table.name: mem
mem
table.column:
This is also written as {Su':excl:nolink}. Some speakers of Klingon pronounce this word as if it were {SSS:excl:nolink}.
This exclamation indicates that the speaker is about to give a command, or is ready to do something or that arrangements have been made for something to happen. ({TKD 5.5:src})

table.name: mem
table.column:
The use of this word involves the concept of deixis. It usually implies the subject is near the speaker, unless the context is set up to indicate the action is taking place somewhere else (for example, using {-Daq:n}). The suffix {-chuq:v} is not used with this verb.[2]
The expression {jISum:sen:nolink} has an idiomatic philosophical meaning, "I'm in touch with my inner self" (in a Klingon way).[2]

When you "zoom in" on something, it looks much closer.
In a message to the {KLI mailing list 2021.02.28:src}, Maltz even said the Klingon pronunciation of the word "zoom" would be {Sum:sen:nolink}.

▶ {jIHDaq Sum raS.:sen@@jIH:n:1, -Daq:n, Sum:v, raS:n} "The table is near me."[2] ▶ {yuQ SumDaq cha'puj law' Datu'.:sen@@yuQ:n, Sum:v, -Daq:n, cha'puj:n, law':v, Da-:v, tu':v} "Detect large sums of dilithium on nearby planet."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to how a word would be defined in the same language. See {ghaS:v} for how to express "X means Y".[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Sup"erman can jump higher than a building.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a Klingon plant, parts of which are used to make cloth.
The song "Pick a Bale of Cotton" has lyrics that go "Gonna jump ({Sup:v}) down, spin ({DIng:v}) around / Pick a bale of cotton."

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of {HurDagh:n}. It is smaller than the {leSpal:n} and the {tIngDagh:n}.
The word "ukelele" means "jumping flea" in Hawaiian.

table.name: mem
table.column: prepare kud in a specific way

table.name: mem
table.column: This might be used for the core of an apple, a planet, or the Sun. But it is not used to refer to the core of a group, which is {qolqoS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a noun referring to the sound (from an animal or otherwise). It is used with {tlhen:v}.[1]
▶ {SuqwIl tlhen:sen@@SuqwIl:n, tlhen:v} "(it) produces a hiss sound"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Based on back-derivation from {Surchem:n}, "force" would've been {Sur:n:hyp,nolink}. The other part is from "F = ma".

table.name: mem
table.column: It sounds like the wind blowing.

table.name: mem
table.column: blow (into wind instrument) to produce sound

This is a general term which is applied to all wind instruments, while {rIl:v:2} is restricted to the {gheb:n}.[2]
This can also be used for blowing out a candle ({weQ:n}). Unlike with {jo':v:1}, air gets out of the thing that's blown onto/into/at (or never goes into it). If {-Daq:n} is used, it implies a miss: air was blown towards the object, but bypassed it.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a category of musical instruments with a flexible bag which is alternately filled with and emptied of air. The sound is produced by the air passing over strips of material which vibrate (see {joQ:n:2}). Known types of {SuSDeq:n:nolink} include the {may'ron:n} and the {DIron:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be shortened to just {veragh:n} when the context is clear.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: From lowest to highest, these ranks are: {tay:n:3}, {Sutay:n:nolink}, {veStay:n}, {Santay:n}, {'Iptay:n}.
This is a rank from John M. Ford's 1984 novel "The Final Reflection". These ranks are used by many Klingon fan clubs, despite not appearing in canon (i.e., in any TV episode or movie).

table.name: mem
table.column: The afterlife for the honored dead, where all true warriors go after they die to fight an eternal battle. The closest Klingon equivalent to heaven.

Klingon spelling used by DeCandido in 2001 novel {Diplomatic Implausibility:src}; confirmed by MO at {qep'a' 17 (2010):src}.
The way this word has appeared in English has been inconsistent between whether hyphens or apostrophes separate the three parts, and whether each part is capitalized. It's written "Sto-Vo-Kor" on {TKW p.144:src}, the script to {TNG - Rightful Heir:src}, and in {Diplomatic Implausibility:src}, which is the convention followed here. However, it has also been spelled "Sto'Vo'Kor" and "Sto-vo-kor" in some materials. The latter way appears in the {paq'batlh:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {bISutlhnISchugh jaghlI' mInDu' tIbej.:sen} ▶ {bISuv 'e' yIwIv; bISutlh 'e' yIwIvQo'.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v}, {Hargh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: If a warrior does not fight, he does not breathe.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just the verb {Suv:v} with the suffix {-chu':v}. From the Klingon point of view, to fight perfectly is to fight to the death.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Brute strength is not the most important asset in a fight.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons are born to fight and to conquer.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to a specific warrior. For warriorhood as concept, see {vaj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Sometimes {SuyDar San'on:n@@SuyDar:n, San'on:n} is also used.

table.name: mem
table.column: Calling someone a {Suy':n:nolink} is considered insulting, comparable to calling someone a "pig" in Federation Standard.[1, p.196]
"Sooey" is a sound used in calling pigs. The Hog Call, a traditional cheer at the University of Arkansas, goes "Woo, Pig! Sooey!"

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TNK:src}, sugar (common table sugar) is translated as {Su'ghar qutmey:n:nolink}. Presumably, then, a single {Su'ghar qut:n:nolink} would be one grain of sugar.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is partially digested and used as a sauce called {quD:n}

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a general term for any kind of raised profile or relief, such as the ridges on the fingertips, the patterns on a car tire, or the profile of a shoe. It cannot be used for the ridges on the forehead, though.
This word is contrasted with {vem:n}, which is the trace left behind when someone touches something. For example, compare {nItlh Su'nIm:n} "fingerprint" (ridges on fingertip) with {nItlh Su'nIm vem:n} "fingerprint" (mark left behind after touching).
When used to refer to the fingerprint, etc., as a body part, this word takes the plural suffix {-Du':n}. (Otherwise, it takes the suffix {-mey:n}.)
In the following examples, the specific finger or toe name can be used instead of {nItlh:n} and {yaD:n:1}.
The object leaving a pattern is often the "negative" image of the pattern.

▶ {nItlh Su'nIm:n@@nItlh:n, Su'nIm:n} fingerprint (ridges on fingertip) ▶ {yaD Su'nIm:n@@yaD:n:1, Su'nIm:n} toe print (ridges on toe tip) ▶ {bem Su'nIm:n@@bem:n, Su'nIm:n} footprint (patterns on sole) ▶ {toqwIn Su'nIm:n@@toqwIn:n, Su'nIm:n} surface of a (rubber) stamp

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a flying insect with largish wings. It originates as a {'ughDuq ghargh:n}.
